II. <u>The Anatomy of Pyrosoma <\u>.
The only specimen of this remarkable animal 
which the writer has had an opportunity of examining 
in the fresh state, was procured on the night of 
the 15th of June 1850 - in about 45o 85 S. lat.
and 110o.30 W. long - The sky was clear but moonless and the 
sea calm; and a more beautiful sight can 
hardly be imagined, than that presented from the 
decks of the ship, as she drifted hour after 
hour - through this shoal of <s>[text?]<\s>
miniature pillars of fire 
gleaming out of the dark sea with an ever waning, ever brightening 
soft bluish light, as far as the eye could reach 
on every side - The Pyrosomata floated 
deep - and it was with difficulty that some were 
procured for examination - and placed in a
bucket full of sea water - The phosphorescence was 
intermittent - periods of brilliancy - The light commenced 
in one spot - apparently in the body of one of the 
<s>[text?]<\s> “zooïds” - and gradually spread from this as 
a center in all directions - then the whole was lighted
 up - it remained brilliant for a few seconds and 
then gradually faded and died away, until the 
whole mass was dark again - Friction at any 
point induced the light at that point - and 
from thence the phosphorescence spread over the 
whole - while the ... is quite quickly taken 
After a while, the illumination arising from 
friction is only local 
So far as could be observed, the Pyrosoma had 
no power of locomotion - any such power arising 
from a contraction of the hollow cylinder is out

II. <u>The Anatomy of Pyrosoma <\u>.
The only specimen of this remarkable animal 
which the writer has had an opportunity of examining 
in the fresh state, was procured on the night of 
the 15th of June 1850 - in about 45o 85 S. lat.
and 110o.30 W. long - The sky was clear but moonless and the 
sea calm; and a more beautiful sight can 
hardly be imagined, than that presented from the 
decks of the ship, as she drifted hour after 
hour - through this shoal of <s>[text?]<\s>
miniature pillars of fire 
gleaming out of the dark sea with an ever waning, ever brightening 
soft bluish light, as far as the eye could reach 
on every side - The Pyrosomata floated 
deep - and it was with difficulty that some were 
procured for examination - and placed in a
bucket full of sea water - The phosphorescence was

in one spot - apparently in the body of one of the 
<s>[text?]<\s> “zooïds” - and gradually spread from this as

then gradually faded and died away, until the 
whole mass was dark again - Friction at any 
point induced the light at that point - and 
from thence the phosphorescence spread over the 
whole - while the creature is quite quickly taken 
After a while, the illumination arising from 
friction is only local 
So far as could be observed, the Pyrosoma had 
no power of locomotion - any such power arising 
from a contraction of the hollow cylinder is out
